Post build list or current specs including monitor: https://pcpartpicker.com/
Provide specific use cases (e.g. video editing, competitive gaming, streaming etc.)

>News
Newly released:
RTX 4080, RTX 4090, Intel Raptor lake, AM5 / Zen 4, 7900XT/X 4070 Ti, Zen4X3D
Soon:
7600XT - Q2 2023
4060 - summer 2023

>CPUs
For light usage/web browsing: Intel i3 or Ryzen 3/G.
For gaming: Intel i5 (K if you want overclocking) or a Ryzen 5.
For multithreaded performance, consider an Intel i7, i9 or a Ryzen 9. Get a Threadripper for heavy-duty workloads.

>GPUs
For gaming, check out the benchmarks for whatever games you play and pick whatever performs best.
For productivity, get a Nvidia Card for CUDA, nvenc, better software support. Don't bother with workstation cards, not worth it.

>PSUs
https://cultists.network/140/psu-tier-list/

>SSDs
Use an NVMe Drive for your operating system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814687
As far as I know all OS do this to some extent, Linux, Windows and Mac have the rendering manager in the kernel but the display server in userspace.
Plan9(front) is the exception because the display is entirely handled by userspace, there isn't even a tty in the kernel.
But I think the TempleOS architecture is the best. It runs the display server in the kernel which is a very nice feature.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814754
its sort of beyond me because i dont understand the low level stuff well, but what are the advantages to the tos approach? I know the os is supposedly exceptionally well built and features some ingenuity at time.
(also whats the pros and cons to the plan9 approach)?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814818
Putting the display server in the kernel would be beneficial since
A) Linux already has a Direct Rendering Manager so there is no reason not to extend it
B) Development would be much easier since Linux has a good build system and is a standalone binary with zero dependencies. You could simply compile Linux, boot it up and you would have a GUI.
C) Potentially better security, for example because more people would audit it.
The plan9 approach is basically a suckless meme. But it might be more consistent and that's basically it.

https://github.com/AUTOMATIC1111/stable-diffusion-webui/tree/disable_initialization

This branch has code to disable weight initialization and downloading/reading CLIP checkpoints. This speeds up creating model from config for me from 13 secs to 3. Model is created from config when you start the program and when you switch betweeen SD1, SD2 and inpainting models. This also prevents downloading 3GB CLIP model file from hugginface.

It would help if someone would test this and report results.

>>90814105
The only restriction is both CLIP and OpenCLIP have 77 positional encodings. If you hijack in your own positional encodings, it can process sequences of any length. Otherwise, no, 77 is the limit.

>>90800543
This is what gpu-hq actually implies:
https://github.com/mpv-player/mpv/blob/6471afecd0277138efdb3a80dec12dbfff75c72f/etc/builtin.conf#L43
Absolutely nothing about this is a stress on any GPU less than 25 years old. But it's bad. spline36 is a polynomial approximation of 3-tap lanczos cargo-culted from imagemagick and rings godawfully. Also, the chroma location of video codecs is chosen expecting that you will use bilinear for cscale, so you're making the chroma planes even blurrier and more offset than they're supposed to be. dither-depth doesn't do what most people think it does and is going to be a noop for 99.99% of content. Sigmoid upscaling causes worse ringing than even gamma in bright areas and the default deband settings will destroy detail but aren't strong enough to actually deband anything. The only correct settings are the downscaling ones but you normally shouldn't be downscaling anyway.

posts.com:
>>90808205
My monitor can't accept 6 as 8 is its default mode, it has 8 bit in its EDID data therefore in Windows/GPU driver settings.
It does 6+2 dithering by a chip, but it's extremely fast and good, all test patterns pass and I can't tell that it does it.
Looks the same as my other real 8 bit calibrated monitor.

So I was right in that speculation, no matter what the GPU will never send anything but what it knows the monitor can receive so it will do the equivalent of dithering or shitty 8 bit data in case it does no dithering, so I might as well dither in MPV and send properly dithered input to the monitor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90799627
If your adjusted speeds are typically low (like the typical 24->60 case), you probably shouldn't use this. I think audio filters have tend to have trouble with pitch correction on values really close to 1 and the resampling from display-resample should be imperceptible anyway. If you adjust speed more extremely though (like 23.976 -> 25 for PAL), this would be worth considering. Probably using display-tempo with good audio filtering settings for pitch correction would result in a better result.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Been using ext4+LVM with encryption for a long time. I might need a new machine soon, and I heard btrfs i better than ext4+lvm, specifically easier online subpartition resizing and easier backups. Is this true? What about performance of btrfs and overall everyday desktop use?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814523
You may want an ext4 ssd as your boot drive and just creating a btrfs raid 1 array (which actually works like raid 10) of hard disks for your storage. There's a small performance hit but spin drives are slow af anyway so it makes no practical difference to me.

I've been running btrfs for years with an array that has 6 drives now (started as 2), and not all are the same capacity. It's survived changing raid levels twice, two failed drives and it's in a home server thats always on. I trust it, the shit about it losing your data is just FUD at this point. Just disable COW for database files and you're good.

I think zfs is probably better but if you use linux then it gets weird with whether or not the licensing makes sense, so idk how well it is actually supported (its certainly not officially supported by the kernel devs). If you don't care then maybe zfs is a better option but btrfs supports heterogeneous sized disks in an array and zfs does not, so for me btrfs is better.

Note btrfs doesn't natively support encryption so i use encfs to create an encrypted directory. I think they should add being able to create an encrypted subvolume, not sure why this isn't implemented yet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814523
I find its performance fine. (that includes running some VMs off it it, without making them nodatacow) I'm not exactly hammering everything 24/7 with random I/O though.

subvolumes aren't really like partitions, they aren't really a fixed size. (well, unless you put quotas on them), the thing that makes them useful is that they're what you can snapshot. A lot of ZFS people do backups by snapshotting a dataset and then using send/receive to fire it over to somewhere else, btrfs does the same trick. It works fine on top of a dm-crypt block device, the only thing is that if you use it's build in RAID/multi-device features you need to arrange for all of them to be unlocked. but that's with any fs.

>>90814705
>Just disable COW for database files and you're good.
that's just FUD at this point too desu. I can't even remember the last time I needed to run a balance to clean up after my VM images. also you want to avoid nodatacow since that also disables checksums. IIRC ZFS doesn't even bother having an equivalent to nodatacow, and people put databases and VMs on ZFS just fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814523
I've started using btrfs just yesterday for my home server so that I can easily do system snapshots before updating, in case anything breaks.
I don't know what the best practice is for encryption though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814705
>Just disable COW for database files and you're good.
Is this really necessary when you can just defrag individual files?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814946
You don't want to have to defrag them in the first place. In my experience files that are heavily modified will take a long time to defrag. I would definitely do it for production database files.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814523
>online subpartition resizing
so easy it's entirely unnecessary
subvolumes share the volumes' space, and don't need their size set or changed
>easier backups
yes, snapshots and send/receive features make it easy and efficient to do backups
>What about performance of btrfs and overall everyday desktop use?
there are some caveats as some of the features do come with performance costs, but nothing you're likely to notice for everyday tasks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814946
defragging them occasionally is usually what you should do, since then you don't miss out on other features like checksums which are disabled when you use nodatacow
only in special cases where that isn't an option, such as for a swap file, should you use nodatacow

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. >>90800176
i switched from android last summer, and it honestly just depends on what you did with your phone
the biggest annoyances are syncing with itunes to transfer music to play on the iOS music app, but everything else works pretty much the same. and you can use a different music player app (like VLC) if you just want to use music downloaded from the internet.
the main reason I switched was because the iphone 13 mini is the only decent small phone on the market, and because i was sick of my android bricking out every couple years. my dad is still using his iphone 7 so i wanted something long lasting as well.
i use windows and mac side by side (windows desktop, mac laptop) and from windows, the biggest annoyance with macos is windows management, but i think theres software that gives you windows like window snapping. maybe someone can give some input here?
anyway the main reasons i switched were because i think apple hardware lasts longer (doesnt get crippling slowdown like my android/windows devices did), the basic hardware is much better (touchpad, speakers, screen) and i like the idea of keeping a device for a long time. my macbook has lasted me 9 years now and hasn't even slowed down a bit.

from a pure usability perspective i prefer windows and android respectively but the other aspects of applel swayed me, at least for portable devices. ill never switch from a windows/linux desktop though.

I also have a 14” MBP which I bought about 6 months ago after having been firmly in the Thinkpad camp since 2006. So far I’m thoroughly impressed and have absolutely zero regrets. It still pisses me off that Lenovo totally bastardized the Thinkpad but oh well.

>>90800176
I switched to iPhone in 2016 with the purchase of a 64GB iPhone SE. I got sick of the low quality of Android apps and I had a series of phones that bricked themselves after less than 2 years of service. After trying out an iPhone 5s for a few months after my LG G4 died, I thought it was worth sticking with the platform. Overall I found the switch to be relatively painless, the big change is using iTunes to sync music, which is a pain. However, iTunes also does a simple, no-nonsense full image backup of your phone, versus the litany of backup utilities on Android (some of which work, some don’t). The built-in system utilities are powerful and very useful. I don’t miss anything from Android and while iOS may be more locked down, I find that it performs core functions a lot better. And the longevity is just insane. I finally upgraded to an iPhone SE3 when I bought my MBP in June. This was after using my original SE for 6 years. I don’t know a single Android phone that has been supported that long.

Windows to Mac OS was a much bigger change. The two operating systems have a very different design philosophy and are quite different to use. I hadn’t owned a Mac since the days of the Classic Mac OS (which is VERY different from OS X) so it was a big change for me. After a few months, though, I can appreciate many of the UI design decisions and overall prefer this environment now. I now find Windows and Linux to be extremely clunky and poorly designed in comparison. It takes some getting used to, but any initial hesitation you feel is probably just getting over old habits.

I'll simply recount my experiences as a former 20 year long Windows power-user buying my first ever Mac last year. 2021 M1 Pro MacBook Pro 16" 16GB RAM.

I needed a new computer/workstation for leisure for and my dev job, I needed a new laptop, a new display, desktop speakers and I was even considering upgrading my 2017 budget iPad. The 2021 MBP more than superbly manages to fulfill each of these use-cases for my personal use.

>The fastest system I've used and consistent at that, no unplugged downclocks like every single other laptop in existence
>Easy 14-16 hour batterylife while watching videos, browsing and listening to music. I never even think about charging or having a power adapter readily available at all. Added benefit of saving me around 100 eur a year on my power bill.
>The ultra low power draw also means there is basically no heat production, at the very most I've measure the chassis at 86F after using it in bed playing games all day
>The speakers don't even compete in the same realm as any other portable computer. They are easily satisfactory as desk speakers (not enthusiast grade). I got rid of my old Logitech speakers. This is especially true for the 16" model which has significantly larger speakers.
>The high PPI 120hz variable refreshrate miniled display with some of the Pro XDR difuser layers is one of the highest quality displays you can get on the market today

These aspects combined completely changed the way I use a laptop. I use it every single day, anywhere I want. Especially using it as a lounging device is something that no other device can compare to. I lie down on my bed, place my MBP on my chest and have my entire *desktop grade* setup with me. My high quality display, speakers, powerful workstation computer and all of my software. Never noticing any heat, never thinking about hooking up a charger. The gigantic glass trackpad also makes this incredibly comfy, while it used to be basically hell on earth with any other laptop.

posts.com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other W10 editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Is Optimize-Offline worth it?
>Should I debloat?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.
If you know what you're doing:
https://pastebin.com/S5VKBirt

>Windows/Office installation guide
https://rentry.org/windowsinstallguide

>Portable programs & partitioning for reinstall-proofing
https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

>Useful programs for a new install
https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>Make 4chan/fwt easier to browse
https://www.4chan-x.net

>I miss the Windows## start menu
OpenShell

WinInfo / Other Pastas:

I need some guidance.

I still do use Windows 8.1, when should I expect everything to stop working? Is there a way to update to other Windows without losing any data?

I have hardisk copies, but I am terrified of losing the stuff still. I know it's silly, but it really gets me anxious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90814562
8.1 is reaching EoL in about a day or so, but this doesn't mean that it'll instantly stop working. You can easily upgrade to 10 via mounting a Windows 10 ISO and running its setup program, though it's recommended to install 10 using something like the 1809 ISO first because using a 22H2 ISO straight up will most likely not work properly when updating 8.1 (or 7).
Then after 10 1809 is installed you can then upgrade to 22H2, which is the latest version. The 10 ISO should be able to pick out what version of 8.1 you're using and then install that version of 10 while also keeping all your personal files and programs.

>>90811734
Right click -> Save Page As... -> /var/www/stopbrowsing/index.html
nano /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/stopbrowsing
server {
            listen 80 ;
            listen [::]:80 ;
            server_name localhost ;
            root /var/www/stopbrowsing ;
            index index.html
            location / {
                        try_files $uri $uri/ =404 ;
            }
}

systemctl reload nginx
Settings -> Home -> Homepage and new windows -> Custom URLs -> 127.0.0.1

posts.com:
>>90812319
>That's a classic pseud take if I ever heard it.
He's (mostly) right.
It's true that the linux host provides many functionalities which might be useful when used in conjunction with emacs, but imagine how much more performant (which isn't to say that it isn't already fast, I've never used emacs so I wouldn't know) emacs would be if it was run in an exokernel coupled with a lisp interpreter (obviously optimized with JIT compilation between other things), with every interface being optimized with the presupposition that you are running lisp and almost no time spent in context switching between the OS and emacs itself. And since it's an exokernel, you can execute linux (or maybe even other OS's) programs if you really want to.
I guess you could achieve similar results with a truly minimal linux installation and emacs, but you probably won't get anything better in terms of speed than what I proposed.

ipID, ipStr, firstVisit, lastVisit
>(unsigned AI int, varchar, datetime, datetime null)
agentID, agentStr, firstVisit, lastVisit
>(unsigned AI int, varchar, datetime, datetime null)
hitID, ipID, agentID, URI, referrer, datetime
>(unsigned AI int, unsigned int, unsigned int, varchar, varchar, datetime)

There are some tables you could use, put it in its own DB separate from your main stuff, you could also do something like creating new table(s) for every new month and containing by month so it's easier to manage. On each page load, you update relevant rows and do your hits table insert with the page URI and the http referrer (skipping that extra info in IP/agent tables would reduce overhead on page loads though).

Then create a cron job or scheduled task to run a script that counts the monthly hits and update totals/averages/etc in some sort of "total stats" or "monthly stats" table (e.g. counting how many page hits for each unique URI [you might want to split before any ? or #, or record ?get differently] and storing that in a table), saving and updating whatever info you want, and setting this to run when your server is at its lowest usage (or hourly or w/e). You can also make that script runable on demand from your admin pages (to get up and running before dealing with cron/schedulers or just to update on demand).
1/2

>>90790064
to clarify, the best database wrapper is exactly this:

function do($query, $args) {
  $pdo->statement->execute($query, $args);
}

function multi($query, $args) {
  return $this->do->fetchAllAssoc();
}

function row($query, $args) {
  $ref = $this->do->fetchAllAssoc();
  foreach ($ref as $row){
    return $row;
  }
}

function single($query, $args) {
  $ref = $this->do->fetchAllAssoc();
  foreach ($ref as $row) {
    foreach ($row as $value) {
      return $value
    }
  }
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90792006
Since you're using var (you should never be using var), the "file" value is able to be changed at any point.

TS doesn't know when the callback function will be called (i.e. 
old => [...old, file]
), it could be in a minute, and any time in between, the var file can change

Solution: change the variable to a const assignment. Ideally you should be using const assignments for most variable assignments (instead of lets and vars), unless there's very good reason you're reassigning variables.

>>90792680

I haven't used mongodb in years, but the general idea for document dbs is to not use joins (relations) like you are here. Everything is mostly non-normalized for max read performance, but the issue with nosql db collections lies here because access patterns, new features, and refactors may require different collection structures which results in complex migrations.

For this implementation, I'd just have all the post objects inside the threads.

>>90794924
I was thinking grid over flex myself, from my understanding of grid I should be able to split a section into a grid of equally spaced squares and set the start and end point of various elements allowing overflow over a set amount of grid spaces.

>what can you tell us about your design, any tips?

I'm not a fan of clutter and things that don't serve a purpose. I like minimalism and empty space, that's an influence for a lot of my photography and design.

I thought about what the purpose of the site was (convey information, show competent design) and how best to get that purpose across efficiently.

A lot of sites I looked at love using fancy graphics to fill up space, lots of distracting colours, animations that serve no real purpose etc. I felt those would distract from the main purpose of conveying information.

Best tip I could give in terms of design (with my style) is really break it down. What is the purpose? What's the best way to achieve this? Dose x element add or distract from that? Look at the design from an outside perspective, dose it work to achieve your goal? Is there anything missing or distracting? Play around with shapes and spaces with what you have, think about how the (western) eye travels across the page (left to right), consider the order in which it lands at certain elements and if that's conducive to what you're conveying.

If you are interested in any other art from (photography, painting, drawing etc) practice it more.

      <h1 className="product-name">{product.name}</h1>

};

>.NET
If you want to learn it for backends can be as easy as using FastAPI to write a backend and as elaborate as Scala/Akka depending on the complexity of what you are building. The C# syntax is ridiculously easy but what you will have to learn are the design patterns and conventions to build backends like the repository pattern, CQRS, Domain Driven Design, OAuth, Dependency Injection and (optionally) microservices. But you can build a backend project in C# without any of these. You should also learn EF Core (ORM) an Identity Framework (for auth, security and user management)

>>90804565

I'm a backend dev (and sometimes fullstack) so take this with a grain of salt, but for the frontend the focus should be on React, Typescript and basic CSS. CSS frameworks (like bootstrap, material ui etc.) are popular for beginners but they should be used minimally. Eventually you're going to spend more time fighting the framework than actually getting any use out of it. Companies also vary in what they use, and spending time learning Chakra UI or react-bootstrap is of no use if you end up applying for a place that doesn't use those. Whereas basic CSS will always be useful. Tailwind is fine since it's basically just shorthand for inline css.

It pays to know some backend stuff so that you understand the concepts of a database and an API etc. that are serving your front end. You'll also likely at some point be in a position where the backend is not serving the stuff you expect and you might need to look into the backend code at least on a basic level. Obviously you don't need to know in-depth SQL or DB optimizations or event based messaging etc. stuff.

>>90786949
Depends on the project. If you just need a traditional monolith site serving a moderate amount of consumers, then it's great at what it does. It's a streamlined experience from prototype to production, and performs well enough for the vast majority of use cases; Especially anything ERP (financial accounting, recruiting, scheduling, order processing, inventory, etc). I would certainly choose it over PHP or Python.

If you need integration with microsoft/windows services, you go with C#. If you need it to be cross-platform or have a hefty amount of computational power, you go for JVM languages. If it needs to be distributed you can bet on BEAM languages. If you need fast input-output and strong concurrency, Golang fits.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90759788
As I said, it's all 3 for 6$ deals, so everything cost effectively 2$ each.
1. Aux Bluetooth receiver - haven't tested it yet, but it looks fine. Buttons feels suprisingly satisfying. MicroUSB cable is ultra short, which was to be expected. Pretty good for the price.
2. 100 chinese bandaids. Might give me band-aids. Time will tell.
3. A very nice little pouch. Comes well packaged with one main compartment and one outer compartment that stretches to fit larger items. Attaches to a belt or molle system. Comes with a carabiner and foam inside so it keeps its form in transport, pleasantly surprised by the quality. Buckle is cheap plastic though. I'd have preferred it without the "sport" on it, but very happy for 2$.
4. Plush shark. I have since learned that plush sharks are a lbtq thing, but whatever. It's cute and it was 2$. Can't complain.
5. Wine stoppers, 2 pcs. Got them as gifts, they should do the job. Enough to keep flies out at least.
6. Folding rubber band gun with rubber bands. The front attachment hook for the rubber bands isn't big enough, so you can't load more than 4 bands at once into the revolver, but other than that it's nice. Might get a second as a gift so I can shoot a friend whenever we meet each other.
7. Chinese lego set. Not sure yet if it'll be a gift or if I will build it myself. If I do, I will report back.
8. Metal hooks. They do what they say, no complaints here.
9. 2m LED strip with motion sensor. I hope the motion sensor works well, but I can't test it at the moment.
10. 5 of those "eternal pencil leads". No idea how well they will work, I hope it's not a normal pencil lead or else it'll be real annoying to sharpen once it wears off.
11. A plant sprayer that attaches to PET bottles. Looks like it'll work and will be great help for the upcoming spring in the garden. Very nice.
(cont)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90760165
(cont)
12. "multitool". It's very small, but that was to be expected. The knife on it is short and dull as shit, but nothing that a few minutes on a sharpening stone couldn't fix. It does have springs that make using the plier part more enjoyable. Since it's so small it could be a nice thing to carry with you when space and weight are at a premium. I do not have too high hopes for the carbon content of the steel, probably going to be very soft and dull quickly.
13. USB-C (M) to MicroUSB (F), USB-A (M) to USB-C(F) and USB-C(M) to USB-A(F) adapters. All advertised as "USB 3.0" and surprisingly the USB ports do have the appropriate amount of pins. Did not expect that. Quite handy.
14. Electronics organizer. Quite a lot bigger than I expected, but I like it. A neon green inside that makes you retinas bleed, but good sectioning.
15. A generic x-acto knife with replacement blades. Very nice.

Overall, very happy with the stuff. Not a single item in there that feels super cheaply made or like it would work badly.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90760736
Last picture, from the other side this time. This set was very fun to build honestly, I might get more now. Also nice of them to include a disassembly tool, since disassembling lego without it is a pain in the ass and the set requires you to rebuild stuff.
Only thing left to do in that pic is adding the stickers. It's nice that they include them and all but one are great, but one of the stickers is ever so slightly larger than the piece it should be added on and that triggered the fuck out of me. I cut the sticker to size with the x-acto knife.
>>90760746
Hard to quantify since I haven't played with lego in ages. The plastic feels "cheaper", but not much. Like the pieces have a little more give than lego used to. But that may also be because it's ages and I use more force now or some shit. All the parts except that piston feel like normal generic lego parts, no weird pieces here. I also wouldn't be surprised if they were compatible with lego. I don't have any to compare, but they seem the same size that lego used to be. Overall, mabe 90% of the way to real lego. In a side by side I may be able to tell it's a copy, but without that reference it's really hard to tell. Also the parts being a bit lighter and probably made from another plastic did not impact the assembly part at all in terms of feel.

posts.com:
I was deliberating this decision for hours.
(The S1 final price will be $670 because of VAT subtraction)

Both have tubeless tire, so they are easy and maintenance free.

X48 has low position headlight.
S1 has high position headlight. Advantage to S1.

X48 has 1,2 kWh battery
S1 has 0,6 kWh battery. Advantage to the X48.

X48 has single charge port, and a cheap low AMP charger which is healthy for the batteries, but you need to plan ahead and charge in good time.
S1 has dual charger

S1 has some annoying algorithm that force you t0 drive slowly in the beginning stretch, then it allows you to speed up over time.
X48 is more unsafe and lets you speed up to max immediately. Advantage to the X48.

S1 has environmentally sealed drum brake.
X48 has double disc brakes. I know these things are low quality or low wuality packaging, so they might be warped/bent during transportation. The probability of fucked up disc brakes are very high, you are going to hear the typical CLANK CLANK CLANK noise when the bent disc rolls in and out of the brak pads. They also get fucked up when you drive in rain and dirt/debris collects on the disc and further damage the brake.
Advantage to the S1.

It's the usual dilemma of do I pick the quality item, or do I pick the item that gives me more battery and mileage for the money.
I'm steering towards the S1 right now because it appears to be the more low maintenance one. But I'm not sure yet.

>>90802951
If you look for used listings in a country that has a decent amount of bikes (this applies to most of europe, I can't speak to countries outside of that because I never tried buying one there) you will find a shitton of used bikes starting at free, the usable ones usually start around 5-10€, a good one (as in "feels like new if you put 30 minutes of work in") around 50€. Branded and specialist bikes will cost more.
Bikes occupy that goldilocks zone of second hand items:
- Most people have one, even if they don't use it too much. As a result there are plenty of them around.
- They don't really deteriorate much from use or storage (except super bad storage).
- They are easy to repair, clean and get back to a good level.
- Most importantly they are big and annoying to store and transport if you don't use them
As a result a lot of people have them, throwing away isn't really an option, they are annoying to stand around if you don't use them, and the amount of people who do this is high enough that the prices are very low. The money is often more of a courtesy thing, it's mostly about getting rid of the bike for the owner. And even if something about it is broken, troubleshooting and fixing it is usually trivial. Closer to urban centers you are more likely to have mroe deals, simply because of population density and partially because of people usually having less space to store the bikes.

>>90812973
>I've never had a Victorinox knife rust so it seems pretty surprising.
Unlike their Swiss army and kitchen knives which are all Swiss made, Victorinox outsources the production of their scissors to a undisclosed (likely Solingen based) German factory. Quality control is less tight and as >>90813351 mentioned:
>Looking at their website they say they a nickel plated and dont specify a metal, so they don't seem to be stainless steel.
Sweden and France are nickel plated, where as their plastic handle ones are stainless steel.

>>90813394
>I went to buy a decent cutlery set and people advised to not put the knives in the dishwasher as they’ll get rust spots, while the rest of the set will stay perfect.
Not putting your knives in the dishwasher is smart to begin with. Shit causes rust spots and blade dulling from prolonged moisture exposure and poor drying, aggressive cleaning chemicals eat away at coatings, and there's a high risk of damaging blades during loading/unloading or having other items scrape again the blade during the washing cycle. Always hand wash and dry immediately after, especially with kitchen knives.

posts.com:
>>90801626
Flashing the stock BIOS will not remove the password AFAIK. It would just be treated like an upgrade or downgrade and preserve settings. It's possible there are some pins you can short to reset the password, but I don't know for sure. I did something like that on an X200T once. Coreboot is the easiest way I know to get the password off there and make it usable, and that's what I'd personally try. It can be hard to find info on password resets because everyone says you stole the laptop or the guy who sold it to you stole it and that it's scummy to remove the password, but installing Coreboot is something people do for all sorts of reasons. I say you might as well remove the password, stolen or not, otherwise it's just e-waste, but not everyone sees it that way.

The Google Pixel 6 literally has a failing touch sensor, a failing fingerprint scanner, the radio modems frequently bug out and fail to connect even 911 calls. There are more issues with it, but the gist is that /g/ doesn’t even think this is noteworthy enough to talk about.

What’s noteworthy and important for you to know is that if your iPhone is 6 years old and you use an extremely degraded battery Apple might optionally downclock the soc if the voltage demand doesn’t match what the battery can provide consistently. This means that apple is enforcing planned obsolescence.

Another hot /g/ issue is that when Apple switched towards their own designed hardware somewhere around 2013 they had a major shift in XCode compatibility between the old and the new, causing a generation of products to fairly quickly (3 years I believe) no longer be able to install applications from the App Store without the latest iOS, which wasn’t supported on the iPhone 3G. This another clear sign Apple is out to get you.

Currently you will have a hard time having a performant computer that is libre. I can recommend all hardware that is librebooted wholeheartly, but compared to what computers can do nowadays it's very slow. For development, chatting, chan-browsing and such it is enough though. I hope for the rise of RISCVs, maybe that could be a viable option in the future.

Do not trust those Companies like Purism or System76 - just detrust anyone, who claims to disable such backdoors. Intellenge agencies are known to tamper with hardware for targeted individuals and I have no doubt that they tamper with hardware made for "privacy-enthusiasts" or whatever. Librebooting is not so hard, even easier on hardware like x61. Buy one of them off ebay and do it yourself, just to be sure there is nothing done with it. posts.sub: /iemg/ & /pmpg/ - In-Ear Monitor & Portable Music Player General
posts.com:
This thread is for the discussion of in-ear monitors and portable music players.

/iemg/ Guide and Hall of Fame:
• https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu
• 7Hz Salnotes Zero (boosted neutral) - $20
• Tangzu Wan'er S.G (mild V) - $20
• QKZ x HBB (big bass) - $20
• Tinhifi C3 (mild U) - $50
• Moondrop Aria Snow Edition (warm neutral) - $80
• [The one that you are using] - $???

/earbuds/ Hall of Fame:
• https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu#Hall-of-Fame1

/pmpg/ Guide and Hall of Fame:
• https://azalush5.hatenablog.com/entry/2022/01/dap-comparison-2022-01
• Your phone
• HiBy R3 Pro Saber 2022 - $210
• Sony NW-A55 + MrWalkman firmware - ~$200 used

/USB/BT DAC/ Hall of Fame:
• OpenHeart CX31993 (budget functional) - $10
• Venture Electronics Abigail (bundle w/ Monk Plus earbuds) - $15
• Moondrop Dawn (3.5 or 4.4) - $70
• Tanchjim Space (dual 3.5 and 4.4 + hardware volume) - $90
• Qudelix 5K (dual 3.5 and 2.5 + Bluetooth) - $110

/TWS/ Hall of Fame:
• https://www.scarbir.com/truewireless
• Samsung Galaxy Buds Pro 2 - $230
• Apple AirPods Pro 2 - $250

• Why use a PMP instead of a phone?
>Better DAC/amp
>More output power so it can drive higher impedance headphones
>Smaller sizes than phones for activities like exercise
>Physical buttons
>Headphone jacks
>Some people can't use smartphone at work/use dumbphones

• How to request advice:
>Budget
>Source (phone or PMP)
>Location
>Kind (in-ear or earbuds)
>Sound signature (or genres you like, important!)
>Past gear and your thoughts on them (important!)

The cheapest option that's still good and reliable and sticks to these ideas is probably gonna be what I'm going for but if it's under 100 dollars I'll be skeptical

Spin fits have a tilting mechanism which helps with seal for IEMs that don't work well with the shape of your ear canal. If you don't have shape-related seal/fit issues it doesn't matter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90803529
Moondrop Spring Tips? Quite different than Spinfits sir in many ways sir.
Spring Tips are delicate, thin, slight sticky, very wide bore, short insertion, sizes for small ears.
Spinfit CP100 type tips are medium, low sticky, normal/narrow bore, medium insertion, benefit of Spinfit design swivel/tilt fit.

posts.com:
been using this thing for a month
a chink eink ui bolted on top an android 11 ("library" is literary hacked into the launcher, setting up a wallpaper behind icon grid is intentionally broken to show plain white)
can install anything from fdroid
don't expect something like lineage to ever run on this due to being obscure and the proprietary drivers
5 responsiveness/resolution modes from crisp and slow to ghosting & dithered and less slow
normal android settings menu and file manager hidden but can be accessed from a custom launcher
to "opt out" of some of the spying you need to access those hidden normal android settings
most settings are accessible in the chink ui though
wonky default combination and multiple options of virtual navigation buttons and gestures, takes couple of weeks of tweaking settings to get truly comfortable with
default document reader program is very good, can write in pdfs with the pen (instant feedback), also takes time to get used to and tweak
clock is never right (unless connected to internet) and alarm is unusable due to the hardcore power-saving
cold and warm backlight whose intensities can be mixed
can read in bright sun without the backlight (awesome)
if you want to view the opened documents in the task switcher you must open them from the stock "library" app, which does not show in other launchers, so you are basically stuck with the default chinky launcher
being able to snap the and firmly hold pen on the edge of the device is underrated
the plain cover that comes with the device is crap because it doesn't snap together when opened, just flaps about unless you hold it
the more expensive keyboard cover is good at being a cover and snaps together when opened, also provides slight corner protection. keyboard connects via magnetic 5pin apple-charger looking connector instead of bt, doesn't require a battery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90782939
The nice thing about e-ink is that it doesn't need to refresh at all. Constantly refreshing like an CRT is completely pointless.
The problem with the refresh speed on e-ink is that you have physical pigments suspended in a liquid that have to move. The fact that you can get a response time of under 20ms with local refreshes is astonishing.
Color makes it far more complicated since you have four different pigments instead of two for ACEP/Gallery. This makes aligning them with electricity a lot more complicated.
The alternative is Kaleido which is using a color filter array like with LCD but that cuts into the brightness since you have no backlight to counter it and into the resolution. The amount and quality of colors is also worse.

I use scripts to rotate anything before sending it to my tablet:
```
for file in */*; do if [ $(identify -format '%[fx:(w/h>1)?1:0]' "$file") = 1 ];then mogrify -rotate 90 "$file";fi;done
## this one liner rotates landscape images 90 degrees so that I don't have to rotate my e-reader

eval convert $(ls */*.{jpg,png}|sed 's/Ch./Ch.\//'|sort -g -t / -k 2|sed 's/Ch.\//Ch./ ; s/.*/ '\''&'\''/') manga.pdf
## finally a sane way. took me hours
##note: this is old and img2pdf does a way better job then imagemagick

## Ditshick Translations_Ch.47 - Insistence food
```

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90808207
If you have a printer and you don't want it taking up space on your desk, move it to somewhere out of the way and use the laptop to serve it to your network.

Disk imaging is a slow, time consuming process; let your old laptop do the imaging/backups in the background so you don't need to worry about tasks on your main rig interfering with the process.

Do you have other servers in your house? Install an SSH client and use it as a terminal so you'll have a backup method for managing your servers if your main rig goes down. Bonus points if you utilize VLANs to separate your management network from your main network.

Play old games? Install Windows XP. Maybe even Windows 98 if it's old enough. You're limited to a shitty IGP so 3D isn't much of an option, but it should run 2D games just fine as well as Doom/Build DOS games (depending on how well they tolerate XP DOS emulation).

Have crypto? Have A LOT of crypto? Consider using it as air gapped storsge for you wallet/keys.

Turn on the wifi in ad hoc mode and set the SSID to NIGGER. Your neighbors and guests will have to scroll past a network called NIGGER whenever they connect for the first time.

>>90782313
Old digital cameras use a CCD image sensor, which is a far more mature technology that produces more consistent results.

The sensor is exposed to light, and the reading are dumped to a processing chip that translates those readings into RGB values, taking exposure and the overall scene dynamics into account. This readout is nearly instantanious so it doesn't produce the shutter roll effect like CMOS.

Modern cameras use CMOS sensors. They were originally adopted because they could be made using the same equipment as other ICs, as opposed to CCD which requires separate machinery. It also supposedly uses less energy, which is ideal for battery powered applications. Due to the physical characteristics if CMOS vs CCD, it is less sensitive to light per unit of area. Also, the way CMOS works is each pixel translates its input into an RGB value independently without taking the other pixels into account. The result is a lot more RGB noise since the readings aren't being normalized against each other to form a coherent image. Each row of pixels is queried one by one, so the top row is going to be several milliseconds behind the bottom row, producing a skewed image during high motion scenes.

CMOS has come a long way since its inception. The design has been greatly improved to compensate for inherently poor low light performance and noise floor, at the expense of requiring special processes beyond standard IC, defeating the cost benefits over CCD. External image processors help level out the noisy RGB floor, at the expense of added complexity and increased energy consumption, negating the energy advantage over CCD.

All this just to match CCD tech from 20 years ago. Professional applications still use CCD if that gives you an idea of which one is actually better.

Millennials will joke about not having good confrontation skills but then go on to make long form video essays about why they're right and everyone else is wrong. Z will not do this. Your average Z is terrified of being SUSPECTED of holding a differing opinion, and will literally start to hyperventilate if you tell them that something they've said is not popular.

Z does not have a concept of a counter culture. Millennials sought out "hipster" or "geek" spaces to resist the commodification of those spaces; Z has grown up with social media and makes the commodification a plus. Z's sub-scenes are but flavors of a broader monoculture, and they like it that way. Millennials will play retro games to try something new. Z's will do it on stream to fold the old media into their collective identity. Z's take huge pride in dressing, speaking, acting and thinking in lockstep. They fear and hate individual deviation from the norm and will ruthlessly hunt it down and stamp it out.

Ultimately, I'd say the difference comes from the fact that Z doesn't know a world before the Internet, but that's just a guess. Regardless, the difference is real and pronounced.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90797692
Go on. Preference testing is invaluable for the development of quality sound but in their studies people only listened to a very limited quantity of well-mixed music not of their choosing. In some studies the subjects could adjust the wide bass and treble shelves but only in large increments. Basically the Harman target is a very low resolution image of what the true human preference target looks like. It's probably V-shaped and would encompass nearly everyone but the exact shape is a mystery and there could be a lot of nuance. It doesn't mean that you wouldn't still need EQ to adjust all the poorly mixed music because closing 'the circle of confusion' depends more on studio monitor speakers being EQed to account for room variance, but age variance is still a factor.

Harman stopped that research in 2019 and so far hasn't released a public target for the B&K 5128 so it will likely get supplanted.

well it depends on what is enough for you, if you are already happy with ksc75 then I'd say about 50% or so. Realistically you are looking at different kinds of setup.

Most people (and with that I mean 90% or so) are happy with good headphones in the range of a couple 100 bucks. Enough choices of good headphones in that range.

If you want to go the full portable 100%, then you're looking at combined setup of dedicated DAP + High end headphones which is several thousands. I'd say between 1000-2000 dollars invested you'll have a good 95% top range sound. The 100% is just not worth it, because you go over desktop / speaker setup budgets then which outclasses headphones/portable setups for the same budget.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90804202
thanks for the link. It has a very useless argument though:
> FTP uses cleartext passwords for authentication
> Even for anonymous public access, HTTPS and web servers have largely replaced FTP
So it’s comparing the security of unencrypted FTP against encrypted HTTP which _also_ transmits passwords in clear text if it’s not wrapped in TLS.
In fact, the headline says
>beware of security risks
which implies a number greater than one, but the only issue they mention is password sniffing - which does not work with ftps (and, assuming the client verifies the certificate, cannot be man-in-the-middle'd either).
So it’s really not a helpful article — and there is simply no other valid security issue that I am aware of.
I’m not denying that the protocol is arcane by today’s standards, but it’s no more insecure than plain HTTP.

#!/bin/bash

cd /sys/class/net/eth0/statistics
old="$(<tx_bytes)"; sleep 1
now="$(<tx_bytes)"

dif=$(($now-$old))
div=$(($dif/1024))

if [ $div -ge 2000 ]; then
   int=$(($div/1024))
   unit="MB"
else
   int=$div
   unit="KB"
fi

echo $int $unit/s

GNU Awk 5.1.1, API: 3.1 (GNU MPFR 4.1.0-p13, GNU MP 6.2.1)

posts.name: notchatgpt
posts.com:
>>90812170
If your bash prompt is starting half way down the screen when using the urxvt terminal emulator, the issue may be related to the terminal's scrollback buffer setting. The scrollback buffer is the amount of text that is stored in memory and can be scrolled through using the terminal's scrollbar or keyboard shortcuts.

Try the following steps to fix the problem:

Open the urxvt configuration file. This file is usually located at ~/.Xresources or ~/.Xdefaults, depending on your system.

Look for a line that sets the scrollback buffer size. It should look something like this: URxvt*saveLines: <number>. This setting controls the number of lines that are stored in the scrollback buffer.

Change the value of saveLines to a smaller number, like 1000 or lower. This will reduce the size of the scrollback buffer and should prevent the bash prompt from starting in the middle of the screen.

Save the configuration file and reload it by running xrdb -merge ~/.Xresources or xrdb -merge ~/.Xdefaults. This will apply the changes to your running urxvt terminal.

Alternatively you can try and run "reset" command in the terminal which will reset the terminal and clear the scrollback buffer as well.

Note that the above steps should resolve the issue, but you may also want to consult your terminal emulator's documentation for other solutions or troubleshooting steps.

Of course it affects people. It's like the change from 2d to 3d in games, or automated farming. It completely changes the game.

All value (money) is created from scarcity. AI floods the market. They are farmers unwilling to change the way they farm, as farmers with tractors and new fertilizers are outcompeting them.

The sensible thing would be to adapt their work. Learn how to use AI. Then use their skills to touch things up. A smart farmer would learn how a tractor works, because their other skills and experience should put them ahead of just a guy with a tractor and no farming experience.

But who gets hit the first? The most worthless of artists. It's not like those who've monetised them drawing on their tablet or painting for livestreams will cease getting money. Newspapers are technically obsolete and so is radio, but things always have their own appeal. Human made art will always exist and have some value. It's just that retards that had some value due to having some art skill can't even beat someone who uses AI.

There will be artists in the coming years who rely 100% on using AI to serve clients.

1. Rust’s memory safety guarantees remove the need for manual memory management, which can be a major source of security vulnerabilities in C programs.
2. Rust eliminates data races and synchronization issues through its ownership system, making it much easier to write code that is thread-safe.

4. Rust’s type inference and generics allow for more expressive code that is both shorter and more expressive.
5. Rust’s extensive use of traits makes it easy to extend an existing library quickly and cleanly.
6. Rust makes it easy to create safe wrappers around external C libraries, which can often be tricky with pure C programs.
7. Rust’s trait system allows for the easy development of generic code and data structures.
8. Rust’s syntax makes it easy to reason about and understand code.
9. Rust has an extensive library ecosystem, with all major libraries having a Rust equivalent.
10. Rust has faster compile times than C, allowing for rapid iteration and development.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90798412
>oh, you mean the programmer eliminates them
More or less. Your code won't compile unless you eliminate them, but just reliably pointing out issues solves like 90% of the problem.
>:hmmm:
Rust's static typing is way ahead of C's, it lets you prevent a lot more. But so is C++'s, to be fair.
>>type inference and generics
>>what is a macro?
auto (coming in C23) does shitty type inference, but Rust can do spooky lookahead to infer a variable's type based on how it's used twenty lines below.
Macros can do shitty generics but they're so painful that they're rarely worth it. Rust uses generics for nullability, to give just one example. They make it a lot more powerful.
>>safe wrappers
>wut does this even mean?
Many C functions come with constraints that are not enforced, only mentioned in the documentation. This char pointer can't be null and must point to a null-terminated string. That integer argument takes exactly those flags. Here's how you check for errors, and if you forget to do that you might end up reading uninitialized memory or segfaulting. And so on. So when you're reading or writing C code you have to double check—can this be null? How do I pass the length of my array?—and if you do it wrong there's trouble.
Rust lets you express that a parameter can't be null, it has array slices that contain their length, it has a Result wrapper that doesn't let you access a value without checking for an error.
So you write a Rust function with a nice signature that itself calls the C function and meticulously follows all the rules. And now the Rust function is safe, it's impossible to call it in such a way that it breaks the rules. That gives you peace of mind.
>>Rust’s syntax
>constanza.jpg
Unironically yes. It takes some getting used to but e.g. the way it does expressions helps with clear control flow.
>o i c, this is a meme post. Good work anon, very funny
Like all ChatGPT posts it slides seamlessly between uncontroversial facts and bullshit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90804962
>Last time I checked I couldn’t run rust on my favorite OS, the GNU/Hurd, because that would require to wrap the whole glibc, including defining every single struct, as has been already done for GNU/Linux and some BSDs.
Those are usually called bindings, not wrappers. They're more similar to C header files. A wrapper would be when you write a new function that calls the existing function, not when you tell Rust what the existing function looks like.
But yeah, that's a lot of work. There actually is a tool to automate it, called bindgen, but to get Rust's standard library working would take more effort than just hooking up libc.
You could write a program without the "std" part of Rust's standard library, in no_std mode. Then you'd only have to declare the C functions you actually use. But since std has all the OS facilities including I/O you'd then need to call libc even for a hello world.
So until someone puts in the effort to make a Hurd port it'll be difficult. That's not an inhuman task, even Haiku has a port, but it takes a lot of work.
Is Hurd your daily driver? Do you use the Debian distribution? I almost never hear about people using it, what's it like?

>>90783321
>Don't be addicted to technology yourself
>Only let them use technology along with you when they're young
Want to keep your kids to an hour or two of screen time per day? Share the same time with them, and when it's time to get off, tell them it's time to pause because you have to go do the dishes or whatever and you don't want to miss anything. Also, invite your kids to help you do the dishes, and let them actually help even when it makes it take longer and get worse results. They'll learn how to be more efficient eventually, and more importantly, they'll build the habit of doing the chores because the chores have to be done. What you don't want is the habit of doing the chores because they're told to; that'll be a huge pain in the ass when they're teenagers and looking for reasons not to do as they're told.

The big thing is to never ever use your phone or TV as a babysitter. That is exactly the kind of mindless consooming that you're trying to avoid. The other big thing is to not be addicted yourself. They will learn from your behaviors, and if they see you shitposting on /g/ for 20 hours a day, they will pick up the same habit. I'd even recommend brushing your teeth and going to bed at the same time that they do. That way, it shows then that adulthood is not about being above the rules and staying up all night is not something to aspire to; rather, if they want to show how grown up they are, they should be dutiful and attentive to their own health and wellbeing.

>>90783321
Didn't read the replies in the thread since they'll all be /pol/ tier psychotic garbage, here's an actual answer:

1) Trying to force your kid not to use technology with nanny software, time gates, etc doesn't work.
You probably have responsibilities and obligations, your kid does not, your kid will spend all their time defeating it which may include going to a friend's house.
Additionally any time you tell a child "don't do this or else" you make them want to do it because they think you're keeping something good from them.

2) You need to offer better, more engaging, more fun alternatives. Fishing, camping, skiing, tennis, building a boat by hand, whatever just try every kind of thing there is until you find one your kid is good at, then encourage it.
Learn it along side your kid, even if just a tiny bit, so you can keep coaching and encouraging your kid to pursue it.

3) Kids use technology in place of friends or social interaction or whatever because it's easy, gratifying, all their friends are their already, and all their friendships are superficial and dangerous (kids bully and betray each other constantly).
4) once you find the thing your kid is good at, ask them if they'd like to go to a camp, training seminar, or whatever related to it where they can meet other kids.

5) Try to explain things in a way to your child that allows them to make a choice, while understanding WHY your desired behavior represents something they may find favorable.
"Technology will rot your brain, you don't want to become a tranny do you?" is worthless.
"I think you'll like other stuff even more than technology, you'll find technology is still something you need to use and important but you'll know about way better stuff that your classmates don't know about."

See the difference?

>>90783321
Remember that everything is appropriate at different ages. Letting a 5yo use a tablet to play games is perfectly fine as long as you moderate the games and the play time (which is easy with parent accounts)
Eventually you can start introducing the computer. You don't need to immediately block the browser because kids below certain age won't be able to read and type on a keyboard efficiently enough to browse the web anyway. And of course, monitor the time and activities. In the end, the best you can do is have your kids be honest with you. Teach them that it's safe to admit that they did something wrong, and explain why that's bad if they do, but don't punish them if they admit to it (but don't ease off the natural consequences of their actions, either). That way, they will likely talk to you if they encounter something disturbing on the web. Optimally, you wanna monitor what they do, but don't shame them for it. Masturbation is normal in kids, and so is being curious about some things. If you're open to explain things to them without shaming them, they will learn to do better than watch porn. Explain that porn is violent and unrealistic. Because yes, kids will watch porn and masturbate to it even at young ages, but they may not get the harmful aspects of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the first step to mitigating electronics addiction is to limit early (pre-K) screen exposure as much as possible: 0sec screen time should be the goal. at that age they're doing good just figuring out how to sit up on their own and how to eat stuff that doesn't come from a tit; there's nothing to be gained by sticking them in front of a screen that early. there's really no reason to do so, aside from the few minutes of peace it might buy you. the next step, as important as the first, is to limit your own screen time. not just in the presence of your child, but altogether. the more time your child sees you spend sitting in front of a screen, the more you normalize the behavior for the child; 'Dad sits in front of his screen all day, so that's what I'm supposed to do.' this happens early enough, and your child likely won't even understand why he feels like coming home and sitting in front of his computer all day, every day is the right thing to. you might think that minimizing the amount of time you spend at a screen in front of your child is enough, but you'll get sloppy and get found, which will teach your child to hide the behavior, which will then go on to exacerbate addiction issues of every variety. past the foundational ages, it becomes a matter of modeling behaviors and working with your children to engage in critical consumption of digital content with them so that they'll learn to consume critically themselves.

if you want your kids to understand computers, start off teaching them math. playing blackjack/21 is a fantastic way to teach even very young children how to count to 21 and teach basic addition/subtraction skills while the natural competitiveness of most kids will help them learn the rules of the game--really, the rules of basic math--more readily than if you were to run a bunch of math drills.
the second thing to teach your kids to help them genuinely understand computers is formal logic, though obviously they'll have to be a bit older for that.

>>90805557
Is very cool, very fast, very fun.
With it you can easily build your own OOP Lua:

Object = {
__name = "Object",
parents = {},
properties = {},
children = {},
functions = {}
}

Object.__class = Object

Object.is_a = function(self, class)
return class == Object
end

Object.__newindex = function(self, key, value)
if type(value) == "function" then
self.functions[key] = value
end
rawset(self, key, value)
end

local function clone(o, seen)
seen = seen or {}
if o == nil then return nil end
if seen[o] then return seen[o] end

local no = {}
seen[o] = no
setmetatable(no, clone(getmetatable(o), seen))

for k, v in next, o, nil do
k = (type(k) == "table") and k:clone(seen) or k
v = (type(v) == "table") and v:clone(seen) or v
no[k] = v
end
return no
end

setmetatable(Object, Object)

Object.clone = clone

>>90751539
>Just the standards

So, for basic effects, the industry standards are:

>Waves (the boomer choice as they were already in the plugin game 30 years ago, but the gigantic number of plugins can be overwhelming for a beginner)
>FabFilter (the modern choice, just a few plugins with zero bloat and a neat interface, used by everyone, can never go wrong with it)
>iZotope (more used for special applications like mastering, audio restoration…)
>for reverb, Valhalla (affordable + no bullshit interface + sounds amazing)

And that’s it. So it would make sense for you to go with the FabFilter bundle + maybe a Valhalla reverb (ValhallaRoom or ValhallaVintageVerb) or the old Altiverb if you like it better. People can suggest 5,000 other plugins that are cheaper, marginally better or whatever like ToneBoosters, Plugin Alliance, DMG Audio and so on, but these are the ubiquitous ones. Walk into any studio in the world and the engineer will likely have Waves and/or FabFilter plugins. Need tutorials or tips? YouTube is full of videos showcasing these plugins, etc.

Also I’d rather rely on these third-party plugins than on FL Studio ones for standard effects (the latter are okay and serviceable, but not great like, say, FabFilter Pro-Q or ValhallaRoom).

Why do you want another DAW? It’s usually best to stick with what you know. I can understand that you want a completely fresh approach after a break though. I did the same myself. As a previous FL Studio user who was back into music-making, this was my path:

>Reaper (felt miserable as you explained)
>Studio One (very neat and pleasant to use, but the bundled content is kinda meh)
>Logic Pro, which I still use now (less snappy to use than Studio One, but having god-tier stock sounds and plugins, a beautiful UI, countless forum topics and videos covering every single question you could have, deep options with MIDI or the Environment… makes it an even better and more productive experience overall)

I tried FL Studio again after that, but wouldn’t trade Logic or even Studio One for it nowadays.

Also, Ableton Live is the most popular DAW today, and everyone should try it, but it did nothing for me so I can’t recommend it personally.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90774833
I have found it very helpful to ignore the Pattern Sequencer completely when creating a song on the timeline. That means loading all your instruments from the playlist (which will automatically assign a track to the mixer and creates a pattern named after the instrument). By creating all new clips in the timeline you are able to dynamically change pattern sizes based on how you resize them in the playlist.

The pattern sequencer is good to work in when you are specifically creating patterns that you might use for live performance or something like that. Once I stopped thinking about the pattern sequencer and started working almost exclusively in the playlist everything clicked. Hope this makes sense.

posts.com: Maybe to more properly define what an avant-garde track would be, we should look at what we know is not avant-garde. For example, 4/4 time isn't very avant-garde, neither is tonal music, or tracks that have a pop/rock structure where there are A and B sections that are different but clearly related to eachother. But obviously we need to draw the line somewhere— what was known as avant-garde 70 years ago would've been something like Schaeffer or Stockhausen, but that stuff is too simple to make with today's technology so it wouldn't fit the description. I know this discussion has probably been done to death, but like John Cage says, experimental music is when you don't know what the outcome is going to be, so copying avant-garde music from the past could not be considered experimental, or forward-thinking, by that definition. What would be avant-garde today would probably something that relates to weird and original ways of using digital effects, but if it were so easy to come up with something original I would have a track ready by now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9079702
Depends on what kind of music you want to do and learning how you personally work best through experience.
I used to be *very* organized and keep a strict schedule while I was in the phase of grinding to raise my base levels up, and iirc my days were broken up something like:
>(after laying in bed thinking about what type of song I want to do that day) 1 hour work on analyzing and attempting to copy elements of chosen song(s). E.g I picked a couple beats by dilla to replicate the drums, a sound from a SOPHIE song, chord progressions etc
>1-2 hours to make sounds for the daily song
>3 hours to write a song
>1 hour to mix

2 days a week dedicated solely to sound design, maybe an hour in one of those days to sort through and organize my sample library...

I have to emphasize that you should keep track of how well you do with certain schedules and how well you do in certain kinds of conditions.
E.g I've learned that if I try to do a whole day strictly trying to write or dick around on instruments, everything after the first hour is basically pointless because I start thinking in circles and never end up following through on ideas....
I basically opted for a system where I try to generate as many ideas as possible while keeping things modular (I reuse ideas and sounds very frequently) because I noticed pretty quickly early on that the vast majority of my ideas are shit so i'm just working around that...

The types of music I make are generally very sound design focused and it's something that's almost always a good investment of time for me (I don't experience a "writers block" equivalent in sound design very often) so it's easy to fall back on and use as filler in my sessions basically.
If I was doing rock or piano focused music etc i'd substitute my sound design for learning more covers or necessary daily exercise etc.

Huge topic... I promised Demi i'd write the guide after I got out of the hospital and totally forgot until your post t b h

>>90795993
>>90796197
I liked Reaper enough to cough up the sixty bux for a legit license. Really, that's very little money for a lightweight yet extremely capable DAW. I occasionally recommend Reaper to people, but I also realize it's simply not the DAW for people who want something super user friendly that comes with very capable plugins.

I typically recommend Ableton Live to people who want to produce electronic music. If you get the full version, it comes with very capable synths, sampler and effects. It's a very intuitive DAW.

I use SunVox primarily now, after years of using Renoise (which I also have a legit license for). I do the bulk of my composing in SunVox and use Reaper for detailed sample editing and final mastering of the stems I export from SunVox.

Really, I could use Reaper for all my composing if I wanted to. Instead of using a sampler plugin, I just place samples on tracks and move them around wherever I want them. I can edit them, chop them, stretch and pitch shift, all on different tracks. I have Reaper set up to make this kind of workflow as fast as possible, but really it's faster by default in SunVox. Trackers are super quick to compose with if you're accustomed to the tracker workflow.

I moved to SunVox as my primary composing software since I can use it on my iPad and iPhone too, which is really convenient. I can laze around on the couch with my iPad and work on a tune instead of sitting at my desk with my laptop. I've even worked with it on my phone several times when I was out somewhere waiting for someone or something. It's definitely a bit of a chore to use on such a small screen, but the fact that I can do it is pretty crazy. SunVox will run on almost anything.

>>90794278
>that is the biggest load of bullshit nonsense ever
It isn't bullshit because of the way modern production works. Now you have super capable DAWs, hundreds of good plugins, dozens of good synths and more if you want to get increasingly autistic. The problem is that most people don't have the experience and skills to manage all of that shit, they have hundreds of plugins installed but only really know how to use 20 or so, and the rest of the plugins they just tweak around or look for presets to see if they get something out of it. Pair that with how people are also incredibly lazy, they just want to watch a quick youtube tutorial and never open a manual, all they want to do is to install a plugin and instantly get to the final result. Then the last one is that if you are unexperienced then you don't know when to use certain plugins from your arsenal, which gives you choice paralysis, and it becomes worse the more plugins you have. All of this will constantly block your creativity flow.
This is why, for people that are like this, it is beneficial to limit themselves, because they simply aren't ready to handle having a lot of things to manage. Limiting themselves in this case would focus their skill and would remove the choice paralysis problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90795625
json is fine, but the main reason against it is not performance but the possibility of corrupt data. For example if the server is updating the json file by writing it to disk and you happen to restart the program or server at that moment then the file can become corrupt. You can work around that with atomic file update but you need to know how to do that properly. sqlite does that automatically.

posts.com:
what's the easiest way to check a file for duplicate strings?
Imagine I have a file made up of ~1,000 lines each line contains ~5 strings and I want to check to make sure no string is identical to any other
Is the easiest way a python script or something along those lines, or has someone already written and released a program which does a similar function?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90798717
People who have this kind of tasks usually just write a script, yes. I'd do it with shell (assuming the strings are separated with '@', for example):
tr '@' '\n' | sort | uniq -d < bigfile.txt > cleanfile.txt

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90798834
oops, "-d" in the middle will make it print duplicate strings. delete it to have unique strings or drop "> cleanfile.txt" to see dupes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90798834
good morning sir
that's not how redirection works
it should be
tr ' ' '\n' <input.txt | sort | uniq -d

if the output is empty, there's no duplicates

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90799501
>How do harddisks know where to look for when we try to read a data on it?
They dont they just contain data.
>let's say how does it know where to read to find cock.png?
The disk doesn't know but the filesystem does. Filesystem support is a part of an OS.
>Is there additional space in harddisk about where to look for certain files?
The filesystem itself. You know like when you create an empty file or a directory it doesn't look like it takes space but it takes space from the filesystem. The filesystem could exist as a one contiguous data or spread as "superblocks". There are over 9000 different filesystems out there.

dvgrab is NOT acceptable for our workflow as we MUST be able to see a preview of the footage as it is being captured, for troubleshooting tapes.
Kino *seems* to work but it is far too complicated for me to deploy in our workflow, and does not seem to be able to export anything useful unless I introduce another step for ffmpeg, which is also unacceptable.
OBS flat out doesn't work, unless you first use VLC (which also has a hard time working) but it then cannot capture audio.

Currently we use windows machines with premire pro for capture, but it works like dogshit with aids on top, and windows itself has a hard time even finding any firewire cards so we play hot potato with cards, cameras, cables and VCRs. Kino on linux has managed to see and "capture" footage flawlessly every time on every camera/card, but it's workflow is about 25 years out of date and I'm not going to be able to teach my staff how to use command line ffmpeg/dvgrab, when we could just brute force premiere pro - it simply isn't worth the potential for human error.

In short, I need a simple, GUI program with a live preview for capturing from firewire on linux.
I don't expect someone to spoonfeed me but if anyone has heard of anything like this, I'd love to be pointed in the right direction. Even a troon's github would be acceptable if it works

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90808361
>However, when I remove the graphics card, it beeps and the power button turns red. Is this some kind of proprietary thing? Shouldn't I be able to use the ports without a graphics card?
Motherboards used to have integrated graphics chips for those outputs, but with the advent of APUs, graphics processing was offloaded to them instead. CPUs still exist however, any many sockets are capable of supporting both CPUs and APUs.
You can look up your specific motherboard model to be sure, but my guess is that those integrated ports only function if you've got an APU installed to handle the graphics processing. If you've got a CPU instead, then the lack of a graphics card means you don't have any way to render graphics even if the motherboard physically has the ports for it.

posts.com:
>>90799501
Yes, this is part of filesystem - on NTFS it's the 'master file system', written near the front of the disk and tells the OS where to find the start of each file, The rest of the HDD is divided into even-sized blocks, and the file system just says 'this file starts at this block'. Then the OS goes to that block to start reading in the file.
This is why files can occupy more space on disk than the file size, any leftover space inside each block is wasted space because it can't be referenced.

What we need is an integrated website, that shows you basically both youtube and Odyssey or whatever on the same webpage, to facilitate the transition. The biggest problem would be the search engine, and the blending algorithm. For the basic interface you could just fork piped or invidious. For the blending algorithm you could just interlace in a ratio which you can edit in the settings. A good default would be 40 60. For the search feature you would have a toggle between Odyssey, Youtube, and both. All thumbnails would show the origin platform icon in the corner.

The video hosting would be provided by Youtube / Odyssey and the HTML files through a browser addon.

This is very important, as it solves the problem of piped / invidious / nitter / etc where the servers costs are covered by volunteers from the goodness of their heart, which doesn't scale.

>What's the best tech field to pursue if I want to work part time (under 30 hours weekly) while still having a steady employer?
Something project based where you get your skill level to the point where you produce acceptable-to-the-company/team output in < 30hr. The company ideally has very few meetings that soak up your time too.

idk which subset of tech that would be for you.
I'd certainly avoid game dev as it has shitty reputation across the board.

Official "part time" isn't really a tech career thing. This isn't dentistry or law where you just don't take patients on friday or cut down your number of clients. You are either on the project or not, from what I've seen. That involves a certain minimum amount of time keeping up with the project and the tech that it uses. The project really only stops "moving" for ~2 weeks of december and any other company shutdown periods you may have.

If you want official part time, switch fields immediately or find explicit shift work as like...technical support for a technical product.

Before you even begin, you'll need:
- a clear scope and guidelines for how it should work when it's done;
- access to the user database;
- infrastructure to host this on, like server/database/backups/domain.
It will need some sort of backend where users can be managed, reports generated, etc.
Keep in mind that not everyone who requests overtime is an employee, no matter how much your boss insists that's the case. One day he'll ask you to "just add Bob the contractor to the system" and you'll realize that fetching the user list strictly from LDAP probably wasn't the best idea.
