>>90806368
You need to have a list of supported applications, procedures, and scenarios in the contract.
I worked for an MSP who once told a customer that "we'll do our best" to recover some deleted data, despite this being outside our expertise. Recovery was not possible. In the end, the customer felt that we didn't "do our best", sued for indirect damages and won in court.
They were able to prove that we could have contracted a specialist data recovery service as part of "doing our best", and our promise (and failure) to recover influenced the customer's decision to not hire their own recovery specialist while it was still recoverable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90804256
My main reasons are:
- I like the simple syntax of Lisp, it's probably the simplest out of all major languages. Arithmetic with prefix notation is also easier to grok once you get used to it.
- Python has become very bloated and complex over the years
- Clojure uses persistent data structures for everything by default. They eliminate many classes of bugs, and it's impossible to do functional programming at good speeds without them.
- In general, if you want FP but aren't into Haskell-style type tetris, there is no better option than Clojure.
- Clojure has much better support for multi-threading
- Scheme is one of the easiest languages to implement yourself, e.g. on an unusual platform or as an extension language in a larger project
- Racket is great if you want to create your own domain-specific language
- REPL-centric interactive development (I can post some videos if you don't know what I mean)
- Clojure people in particular just make everything they touch more simple and usable. For example .edn is pretty much the best data format there is, and it's integrated into everything in Clojure; Hiccup syntax is much nicer to write than regular HTML, and so on.
- Clojure and Python can use most of each other's libraries, so Python's larger ecosystem counts for very little
- Python is used by a lot of beginner programmers, so much of the code you find in the wild is of low quality. Clojure is mostly used by experienced Java devs who wanted a simpler and more FP-centric language, and by experienced Lisp programmers who wanted to stop being NEETs.
- as a general gripe with C++/Java-style OOP languages, see https://youtube.com/watch?v=aSEQfqNYNAc
- Main thing I still like about Python is exploratory programming. In Gimp, looking at what methods a Python object (e.g. the image or the layer) supports will give you a quicker understanding of what you can do with it than the Guile console can.

https://github.com/abicky/nodejs-repl.el
I just wrote a function that users of nodejs-repl.el may find useful.

;; restart a nodejs repl quickly, because reload() is often not enough.
(defun u/nodejs-restart ()
  "Restart a nodejs repl."
  (interactive)
  (if (equal (buffer-name) "*nodejs*")
      (progn
        (kill-buffer "*nodejs*")
        (delete-window)
        (nodejs-repl))
    (message "Switch to a *nodejs* buffer first, please.")))


The reload() I mention in the comments is this javascript function I often use to reload modules.
function reload(module){
  delete require.cache[require.resolve(module)]
  return require(module)
}


It's used similarly to require to reload a module. Sometimes, reload isn't enough get a completely fresh view of new code, so that's why I implemented u/nodejs-restart.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90812723
>>90812754
The GPU only has 7ms to render the frame, and it has to know the position of your eye before it begins. All of the time spent running the AI following your eye position and calculating what your eye position will be by the time the frame rendering is completed is time and resources taken away from rendering the actual frame. If it takes the AI 2ms to determine your eye position, then the GPU only has 5ms to render the frame. At that point, it probably could have just rendered the entire frame at full quality, and saved the cycles that were used to run the AI.

Then, if the AI guesses wrong, then the frame comes out looking like shit and the whole thing was basically wasted effort. If the AI only guesses right 90% of the time, then 10% of your frames are trash and you might as well throw them away. At that point, you can just get rid of the AI and render all of the frames at full quality and have 10% lower framerate.

>Why is the new series of GPUs so comically large?
Because nvidia and AMD jacked up the power their GPUs use to beat each other to "the best gaming card" because the competition is so fierce they have to pull every lever. Neither feels that they can win with just a node shrink from TSMC and architecture improvements.

This higher power means more heat. More heat needs more cooling, and more cooling needs bigger sizes. The coolers are limited by physics at this point. Everything you could think of to improve a cooler without making it bigger - the answer is "yeah they're already doing that" or "no, that would make it too loud/expensive".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90809586
It's a notoriously terrible card. It's so bad it's actually a meme. There are Youtube vids that do a better job explaining why than me, but I'll take the opportunity to shit on this card anyway:

1.) This was one of the earliest (first?) examples of nVidia engaging in the questionable business practice of marketing multiple versions of a particular product line under the same model name, with no distinction between the different versions.

1a.) Unless the box says so, you have no way of knowing whether you got the shitty(er) 64-bit memory bus or 128-bit.

1b.) They came in a wide variety of clock speeds ranging from library computer passive cooled units to slightly-less-shitty 20mm fan-cooled units. Again, the marketing makes no distinction between the two even though there can be up to 200% performance difference in some cases.

2.) It was marketed as a "DirectX 9" compliant card, but only insofar as it checked off the boxes to meet DX9 compliance on paper. Realistically, this card could barely run DX8 games at acceptable frame rates.

3.) Even the upper-end 5xxx series yielded underwhelming results within its class. It was in some ways a downgrade from the Geforce4 series in terms of raw performance and its inability to deliver on the new APIs it was heavily marketed for made it even worse. It was simply a bad architecture, like how Intel's Nutburst was doomed from the start.

All that said...

This was my first GPU, $120 new in 2003. In retrospect, it wasn't much of an upgrade over my S3 ProSavage integrated graphics. On UT99 (a 4 year old game at the time), it was most comfortable on 640x480. 800x600 was "okay" but not as competitive with the occasional slowdowns and 1024x768 was unusable at 20FPS. Dropping the color depth to 16bit helped some but nothing really made this card happy other than dropping to resolutions that I'd be running on the IGP anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90813662
Rust is very into static typing and hard guarantees. It doesn't want to just lazily do whatever LLVM supports. I don't use C++, so correct me if I'm wrong, but I hear it's pretty loose about constant evaluation, so you can annotate a function as constexpr even if with certain arguments it couldn't be evaluated at compile time. Rust wants the body of a const fn to only contain calls to other const fns and so on all the way down so that it's guaranteed to work.
A benefit of this is that as soon as you annotate a function as const you can't accidentally make it less const and break backward compatibility. You'd just get an error even if you don't have any calls that would force the matter.
A drawback is that you now need to be able to say things like "this function is const only if T's add operator is const", so the user-facing design becomes more complicated. Features are added piecemeal, so it keeps getting more powerful, but it'll take a long time before it has parity with C++, if ever.

>>90813749
It doesn't have a standard but it does try to have principled rules.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90813981
Traffic lights are lock-free. You don't contend for a traffic light. The system as a whole can always progress, assuming exits from the system are not blocked.
Furthermore, traffic lights are wait-free. The time it takes for you to cross through a traffic light is bounded.
Roundabouts are neither lock-free (cars could enter and refuse to take an exit, blocking it forever) nor wait-free (you could wait forever to enter one).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90812946
>>90813039
Done: https://pcpartpicker.com/list/BgtJd9
It was pretty close so there's only one major change in the video card. Everything else was just a matter of cost optimization.

>CPU
This is closely matched with the 5700X. The 13400 will be slightly better for gaming and slightly worse for production. Small differences either way. The main advantage is that B760 is a better platform. If you want to penny pinch then swap the 5700X back in.
>Cooler
Better than a 212. You could drop this back to one of the various <$30 120mm towers if you don't mind some noise. I see a Peerless Assassin for $50 but it's white. If that doesn't bother you then it would be worth the upgrade.
>RAM
Always better to buy a matched kit. Especially for newbies. 6000C36 was only $10 more than 5600.
>SSD
Just a cost optimization. If the 980PRO, or any other top end PCIe 4 drive, is cheaper on the day buy it instead.
>Card
This is the big change. Most production software prefers Nvidia. You would do well to actually read up on how your suite behaves. The 6750XT definitely offers more gaming performance; if it's only slightly worse in production then it may be fine to swap.
Also this is a bit of a cheap model. Will be louder under load - if you have some margin in the budget it'd be nice to upgrade this.
>Case
I've left this as-is. You can get better performance for that money but there's an element of aesthetic preference in cases. If you really like the design then it's not a /bad/ case so don't sweat it. An extra intake fan will go a long way to improve the cooling.
>PSU
Just another cost optimization. If you intend to upgrade the card to an xx80-class later then get more wattage.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90809475
>The content is irrelevant.
By this I mean there is no financial incentive to run an eepsite so nodes earning money would not affect "content" whatever the fuck that is on a privacy protocol.
You're extrapolating cancer in another market to this market. If you earned money running Tor nodes as well it still wouldn't affect hidden services or the clearnet you could access, people would just earn some money running nodes which would mean more nodes.
The hard part is making it sustainable to pay nodes. One easy way would be to payout crypto to all nodes that maintain uptime and speed standards and having people just buy that crypto coin as a method of "donating" to the entire network nodes. The more people buy the token the more node runners earn, and more nodes start running. Simple. Of course there's altruism in people having to pump the crypto, but for something like Tor or I2P I think that would be fairly easy. It's like donating to the foundations developing basically. Another point, a percentage of all donations could go directly to foundation/developer wallet so they get funding too. It's quite genius as a concept as long as the underlying idea is useful. I'd gladly buy and burn some privacy tokens as a way to decentralize pay for more nodes.
I'd also gladly run a node for free though, but I'd be more likely to run it if I earned a dollar or two a month on sharing the bandwidth.

Long lasting bulbs were available even in the 90s but few wanted them because the lumens per watt were terrible. Incandescent bulbs typically burnt out because of thermal expansion and contraction of the delicate filament. >>90809335
So what we have right now in the field of quantum computers are quantum annealers. These systems with Qbits are effectively a form of accelerator that is basically doing computing in memory, there are a lot of these sort of accelerators emerging in the market now, virtually none of them apart from two big players are quantum anything. There is still really hardcore work being done to conclusively prove if quantum speedup exists at all, how much of an advantage it is if it actually exists. There has been an ongoing cat and mouse match for years now where some quantum computer like a Dwave claims to have proven quantum speedup, then another group of researchers with a standard server rack and some GPUs does the same calculation just as fast.

Regardless, these machines are all accelerators for specific types of workloads. They're not even attempting to replace anything like a CPU as a generalized processing element. They're no more capable of that than a current GPU is capable of replacing a current CPU. Its apples and oranges.

>>90809025
I believe that Moore's Law is not dead for a few reasons.

First, Moore's Law is not a physical law like the laws of physics, but rather a prediction based on past trends in the field of computing. It states that the number of transistors on a microchip will double approximately every two years, leading to exponential increases in computing power. While this prediction has held true for several decades, there have been some recent indications that the pace of progress may be slowing down. However, this does not necessarily mean that Moore's Law is dead.

Second, there are still many avenues for technological advancement in the field of computing. While it may be more difficult to continue shrinking transistors, there are other ways to increase computing power, such as developing new materials and designs for microchips, or using novel approaches like quantum computing.

Finally, it's important to remember that Moore's Law is a prediction, not a guarantee. It is based on trends and patterns, but it is not a law in the same sense as the laws of physics. It is possible that the pace of progress in the field of computing could accelerate or decelerate in the future, but this does not necessarily mean that Moore's Law is dead.

Overall, while the pace of progress in the field of computing may be slowing down, I believe that there are still many opportunities for technological advancement and that Moore's Law is not dead.

yes, people have made things like this before, no, they don't keep spinning
the reason is simple, the system has losses (inefficiencies) that cause it to slow down until it comes to a rest (stops)
only in theory with a 100% efficient motor and generator can it keep spinning, but even in that case you cannot power anything else with it, because that load will take energy from the system, slowing it down
in reality, the motor and generator cannot be 100% efficient, as there is friction, which leeches energy from the system, converting it into heat, so even without a load they will slow down and emit heat on their own, the amount of heat they emit is perfectly equivalent to the energy you put into the system to spin them up
it all balances out in the end

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Reminder that the "VPNs" that youtubers shill you are proxies, not VPNs. A VPN is a private network that is inaccessible to the rest of the internet except through the gateway, like an office network that lets people working from home connect through a gateway.
The proxy companies renamed themselves to VPNs because they realize they could convince normies that the "PN" part has something to do with endpoint privacy so it sells better than being called a "proxy".
The only relation these proxies have to VPNs is that they use VPN tech under the hood (OpenVPN / Wireguard).
Also a bunch of them run a side-business of letting spammers pay to send traffic through your computers using that same VPN connection, so that it appears from residential IPs and is harder to block.
So yes, if you really want a proxy so that you can hide your client IP, just create your own server like the other anon said and use it through wireguard / openvpn / ssh.

>>90813903
>>90813537
>Create and log into a Mi account
>Go to developer settings and tap Unlock bootloader
>Apply for unlock
>Wait 7 days (no joke, that's how it works)
>Download and install Mi Unlock software on your PC (download it from Xiaomi's website)
>Plug your phone and follow the steps (phone will be factory reset so backup your stuff)
>After it reboots you should see an open lock icon on the boot animation, it's done

to install a custom ROM you just need to find one that works for you, LineageOS, Pixel Experience and Arrow OS are great choices if you want something light and simple, if you want customization go for something like CrDroid or EvolutionX, then follow the steps each maintainer says, most of them need you to flash a custom recovery file and install the ROM through it

if you like MIUI you can also install the Xiaomi.eu custom ROM, basically a modified MIUI with minimal bloat, spyware and ads

you can also disable ads for the majority of the system apps on stock MIUI under each app settings page, use an ad blocking DNS, VPN or app, replacing system apps with open source/ad free alternatives like Simple Messaging instead of the included messaging app or Mull Browser instead of Chrome

#include <vector>

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <time.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <algorithm>

#define MAXENT 1000000


struct Entity
{
    size_t id = 0;
    size_t next = 1;
    bool avail = false;
    float position[3];
    Entity()
    {
    }

    void update()
    {
        //printf("updating %d\n",id);
        for(int x = 0; x < 3000;++x)
        {
            position[x%3] = ((float)x) / 100.f;
        }
    }
};

int main()
{
    std::vector<Entity> entities;
    entities.resize(MAXENT);
    auto make_avail = [&](std::set<int> list)
    {
        for(auto it = list.begin(); it != list.end(); ++it)
        {
            auto next = std::next(it);
            int i = *it;
            entities[i].avail=true;
            entities[i].id = i;
            if(next != list.end())
                entities[i].next = *next - i;
            else
                entities[i].next = MAXENT - i;
        }
    };
    srand(time(0));
    std::set<int> l;
    for(int i = 1; i < MAXENT/10; ++i)
    {
        l.insert(rand()%(MAXENT-1));
    }
    make_avail(l);
    int ne = entities.size();
    for(int i=0;i<ne;++i)
    {
        auto &e = entities[i];
        if(!e.avail)
            continue;
        e.update();
    }
    return 0;
}

>>90799320
For optimal cache efficiency you would want to restructure Entity so the positions of all entities is just an array.

The most expensive thing in B is the function call, however. If the compiler is dumb the local state of main will be pushed on the stack each time, making it even slower.

it would be better to have a separate vector of just the avail flags. Then you can fit 64 entities into a single cache line and even do

>>90804547
>So "kotlin" is a function that receives "jvm" as parameter, but how "version" and "1.7.22" interacts with the previous function? They aren't parameters.
It's shorthand. kotlin("jvm") gets transformed into 'id "something.long.i.cant.be.assed.to.look.up"' (whether directly or by applying to the implicit model) and then gradle uses that plus the (entirely separate) version definition afterwards to configure how exactly to go about building kotlin (targeting a standard JVM).
I don't like such shorthand trickery. When they work they're fine, but when they break you can't debug them at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90801803
Using exceptions is fine, unless the performance really is critical.

As a library author, though, I rarely use exceptions. The problem is that exceptions are easy to ignore or forget about when you might want the caller or someone towards the top of the callstack to actually know about the error. Generally speaking, "which errors I want to handle" vs. "which errors I don't care about even if the program crashes" is very application specific, and exceptions are generally worse for an non opinionated approach to it. That isn't even mentioning that many people will completely avoid anything that throws, where code that doesn't use exceptions can be pretty easily wrapped to throw whatever.

>Trying to Learn Rust: Day 0
I decided to shit on the pot instead of constantly putting off learning the biggest meme language West of the Pecos.
The first exercise that the docs instructed me to do - after teaching the basics of operating the compiler and build system - was to create a game where a random number would be chosen, and then a user input would be given, converted to an unsigned int, and then compared with the random number. If correct, it would then break a loop the input-compare process was in. If incorrect, it would use the switch (Called by Rust a "match") to print messages if the number inputted was lower or higher than the number. This was obviously done with error checking that would repeat the input process in the case the user entered something not valid as an integer.
It was fucking pain doing it, mostly because of the verbosity that the language implements. It was also stupid how I had to include the calling of the operator used to store user input *within* the loop rather than without, because logically that would try to create a new operator of the same name with each iteration of the loop - as opposed to calling it once outside the loop, and then having a new input routine per loop.

this is going to be hell

>Auto-updates

P3A removes your IP address from the requests, doesn't collect personal information, the list of metrics is public, the code is open source, etc., can be disabled with one click

Opt-in
>SafeBrowsing

>Brave Rewards
Opt-in
>Miscellaneous requests worth noting

>The rankings were revealed in a research paper published by Trinity College Dublin computer scientist Doug Leith. He analyzed and rated the privacy provided by Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Apple Safari, Brave, Edge, and Yandex. Specifically, the study examined the browsers’ sending of data—including unique identifiers and details related to typed URLs—that could be used to track users over time. The findings put the browsers into three categories with Brave getting the highest ranking, Chrome, Firefox, and Safari receiving a medium ranking, and Edge and Yandex lagging behind the rest.

It's like if to stop minors from burning gacha in vidya a law was passed that requires real ID for every online game. Why not, you know, ban or heavily regulate gambling in vidya ? The solution is really to gather with your friends on trustworthy environments, do cost effective measures to get past the 14 eyes and just live your life trying not to lose sleep over this. It's not healthy to get obsessed over what you can't change. Worry about what you can do, do it, and give little care for the rest.
